text: A Chokusaisha () is a special type of shrine where a Chokushi, who is a representative of the emperor performs rituals. These shrines are also known as Chokushi Sankō no Jinja (). There are sixteen shrines that have been designated as Chokusaisha, and they are listed in the table below. Name Name Location Kamo-jinja () Kamowakeikazuchi-jinja () Kita-ku, Kyoto Kamo-jinja () Kamomioya-jinja () Sakyō-ku, Kyoto Iwashimizu Hachiman-gū () Iwashimizu Hachiman-gū () Yawata, Kyoto Kasuga-taisha () Kasuga-taisha () Nara, Nara Atsuta-jingū () Atsuta- jingū () Atsuta-ku, Nagoya Izumo-taisha () Izumo-taisha () Izumo, Shimane Hikawa-jinja () Hikawa-jinja () Ōmiya-ku, Saitama Kashima-jingū () Kashima- jingū () Kashima, Ibaraki Katori-jingū () Katori-jingū () Katori, Chiba Kashihara-jingū () Kashihara-jingū () Kashihara, Nara Ōmi-jingū () Ōmi-jingū () Ōtsu, Shiga Heian-jingū () Heian-jingū () Sakyō-ku, Kyoto Meiji-jingū () Meiji-jingū () Shibuya-ku, Tokyo Yasukuni-jinja () Yasukuni-jinja () Chiyoda- ku, Tokyo Usa-jingū () Usa-jingū () Usa, Oita Kashii-gū () Kashii-gū () Higashi-ku, Fukuoka == References == == Other websites == * Sakamoto Koremaru: "Chokusaisha".
